title: Edmund Bourne (cricketer)
text:
Edmund Horace Bourne (14 February 1885 – 7 August 1962) was an English <a href="cricket">cricket</a>er. Bourne was a right-handed batsman who bowled right-arm <a href="Spin%20bowling">slow</a>. He was born at <a href="Stoke-on-Trent">Stoke-on-Trent</a>, <a href="Staffordshire">Staffordshire</a>.
Bourne made his debut in <a href="county%20cricket">county cricket</a> for <a href="Staffordshire%20County%20Cricket%20Club">Staffordshire</a> in the 1904 <a href="Minor%20Counties%20Championship">Minor Counties Championship</a> against <a href="Dorset%20County%20Cricket%20Club">Dorset</a>. Between 1904 and the start of <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a> in 1914, Bourne made 49 appearances for Staffordshire in the Minor Counties Championship. In 1912, he was selected to play in a combined <a href="Minor%20Counties%20cricket%20team">Minor Counties cricket team</a> for its inaugural appearance in <a href="first-class%20cricket">first-class cricket</a> against the touring <a href="South%20Africa%20national%20cricket%20team">South Africans</a> at the <a href="County%20Ground%2C%20Stoke-on-Trent">County Ground, Stoke-on-Trent</a>, in 1912. In what was Bourne's only first-class appearance, he batted once in the match, scoring 16 runs in the Minor Counties first-innings as an <a href="Batting%20order%20%28cricket%29%23Opening%20batsmen">opening batsman</a>, before being dismissed by <a href="Aubrey%20Faulkner">Aubrey Faulkner</a>. Following World War I, he made five further appearances in the Minor Counties Championship for Staffordshire, with his final appearance coming against the <a href="Surrey%20County%20Cricket%20Club">Surrey Second XI</a> in 1912.
Bourne had three brothers, all of whom played <a href="Minor%20counties%20of%20English%20and%20Welsh%20cricket">Minor counties</a> cricket for Staffordshire. Bourne died at <a href="Earlswood">Earlswood</a>, <a href="Surrey">Surrey</a>, on 7 August 1962. He was buried at <a href="St%20Mary%27s%20Church%2C%20Reigate">St Mary's Church, Reigate</a>, next to his wife, Elsie.
